Pursue your dreams and you shall be happy!  11 years ago, with a 3-year Masters degree in Electrical Engineering from US of A and loads of over-confidence on my mind, I went knocking on the doors of #intel in India for an opportunity to start my dream - To build circuits , tiny little circuits.  To my disappointment, I failed, and I failed over and over again for next 7 months and remained job-less. The failures eventually cut through my over-confidence and brought me to ground. All this while during my job hunt, I was receiving calls from software firms to which I was hell bent to not interact, thanks to my ego,   My ego -> "I have a MS in EE from USA, why should I take up a software job, my 3 years would go down the drain"  But little did I know that the universe was plotting against me all this while. My mother, a banker, gave me an ultimatum (as I was free loading under her roof for past 7 months),   "Rajesh, take up a job, any job, keep your pursuit for an electronics job while you work there, this will help your resume rather than doing nothing"  2011 September, I started working Amazon's Hyderabad R&D center as Dev Ops engineer. This was a time where Amazon.com was yet to foray the Indian e-commerce world. I learnt about e-commerce Industry, learnt to code, understood Data-centers and even explored Extract Transform and Loads of Data Transformation. #amzn. This was probably an interesting phase of my life where I felt, "Hey, this is a great place to work, I am learning, but what about my dreams to build circuits?   Yet again, 7 months into "Dev-Opsing", opportunity knocked my door in the form #synopsys . I received a call from the hiring manager who looked up my linkedIn profile ( yes, year 2012 LinkedIn was beginning to show its value) and asked if I would be interested to join their team as an Intern. I jumped out of my seat and accepted the offer without a second thought. I quit my decently paying job at Amazon and joined as an intern at Synopsys-India, building Process Design Kits. This marked the beginning of my journey in the world of semi-conductors.  Today, I complete a decade in this Industry and I am on the verge completing 3 years at Intel, where my hunt had all started. I could not have been happier than what I am today <3.  There is nothing more satisfying than doing what you love!  I have become an electronics engineer, who loves to code , and that is a combination that has helped me automate circuit design.  I am thankful to my failures and to all the Leaders, mentors and friends from #amzn #synopsys and #intel who taught me the importance of being patient, creative and most importantly to do what you love <3.  Cheers!  #electronics #electricalengineering #careerstories #vlsi #semiconductor

content: A well-known Coventry engineering name has been re-born after a £4.2 million investment and is looking to expand.   Penso Group, went into liquidation in May 2021 due to a combination of Covid-19, the fall in demand for the production of new aeroplanes and taxis, and a global shortage of semi-conductors it needed to produce lightweight pods for the home delivery sector. With advice and support from the CWLEP Growth Hub, the future is now looking much brighter, after they’ve secured a a 29,000 sq ft Technical Centre in Westwood Way and received a £4.2 million investment from McDermott Group. Read their story here  https://bit.ly/3gMQ0Id

Yesterday was about #relationships and when thinking about Asia, size matters, both physical and population.  In thinking about expanding, a big market to sell into always helps.    Asia is a really big place, but because the US is the biggest single language country in population, sometimes we forget how big.    Some perspective on the geography, in the US we think flying from NY to LA takes long at 4.5 hours.  If you went from Singapore to Mumbai, Beijing, Tokyo, or Sydney, those trips would take a minimum of 6 hours.    The above destinations from Singapore are the Big 4 - Australia, China, India, and Japan.  These are the markets everyone opening up in Asia is going after.  These markets present very different competitive dynamics. By example, Australia’s continent is as large as the United States, but with a population of 25.8 million mostly living on the coast.  Think about how distribution would work if everyone lived on the coastline or borders of the US.  Contrast that with India and China both over 1 billion people rapidly moving up in disposable income.   	 Small in land, does not mean small in impact.  In Asia you have many countries which are not the physical size of the Big 4, but have significant economic clout.  Singapore and Hong Kong in financial services, South Korea and Taiwan in high technology and semi-conductors, Malaysia on natural resources.  Each of these countries have their own cultures and heritage, so you have to understand its history before jumping in.    In addition to India and China, there are many countries of Asia that have populations close or above 100M, Indonesia, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Japan, Philippines, and Vietnam.  As a comparison, Germany with 83M people is the largest Western European country.    Having big markets to go after is great, but focus creates success.    Please share your thoughts or an interesting fact about your market.  #entrepreneur #international #sales

We would like to congratulate and welcome to our Supervisory Board two new members, Edith and Susan! We are grateful and excited to have them join the Board and bring their unique talents, expertise and perspectives to the work of Butterfly Works, in order to further our vision of creating a world in which people have a say in the future they want. Meet our newest butterflies...  Edith van der Spruit has worked with PUM Netherlands senior experts, a volunteer organisation, since 2012. She works as an expert in the textile design sector and gives advice to SME’s in emerging markets and developing countries. Edith is also a member of the Ethical Commission. Prior to this, she was the country coordinator for Sri Lanka for PUM and the CEO of WO=MEN Dutch Gender Platform, a unique international lobby platform that addresses human rights and specifically, unequal (power) relationships in the field of gender and sex.  After her studies at the Academy of Visual Arts in The Netherlands, Edith lived in French-speaking Africa for more than ten years. During this time, she inspired women to rebuild their lives as entrepreneurs, after years of violence and war. She developed forms of micro credit and local savings systems that are still used to this day.  After completing her Master’s degree in Public Administration and Communication, Edith worked as the Director of Social Development in several municipalities. In 2012, she returned to Africa to be the Country Director for Oxfam Novib in Eastern DRC.  Susan van Esch has 20 years of experience at the intersection of social development and culture. Trained as an anthropologist, Susan approaches social issues from different perspectives and strongly believes in bringing unexpected parties together for sustainable change and innovation. She previously did this for organisations such as Oxfam, Cirque du Soleil, Dance4Life and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Inclusion and participation of the target group, especially young people, is a special focus in all her projects. Susan is currently head of the Master's program Crossover Creativity at HKU, where creativity is used to tackle societal challenges. Trains, travel and reading are amongst her favourite things to do, particularly when combined.  Thank you to all who serve on the Board, and we look forward to working together to advance our work within the international development sector.

SOFTWARE IS IMPACTING THE WORLD! FEEDBACK-LOOP is FASTER THAN EVER!   Historically, stories of breakneck growth involved either computer software, which offers nearly unlimited scalability in terms of distribution…    OR… Software-enabled hardware, such as the Fitbit fitness tracker or Tesla electric car, whose software component allows the company to innovate on software timescales (days or weeks) rather than hardware timescales (years)!    Moreover, the speed and flexibility of software development allow companies to iterate & recover from the inevitable missteps of haste!   What’s especially exciting these days is that software and software-enabled companies are starting to dominate industries outside of traditional high tech!    Marc Andreessen has argued that “software is eating the world.”    What he means is that even industries that focus on physical products (atoms) are integrating with software (bits).    Just like Tesla makes cars (atoms), but a software update (bits) can upgrade the acceleration of those cars and add an autopilot overnight.   The spread of software and computing into every industry, along with the dense networks that connect us all, means that the lessons of “quantum-growth-hack” are becoming more relevant and easier to implement!    Even in mature or low-tech industries!   To use a computing metaphor, technology is accelerating the world’s “clock speed” (the rate at which Central Processing Units [CPUs] operate),    making change occur faster than previously thought possible!   Not only is the world moving faster, but the speed at which major new technology platforms are being created is reducing the downtime between the arrivals of each wave of innovation!    Before that, individual waves would sweep through the economy one at a time—technologies like personal computers, disk drives, and CD-ROMs.    Yet today, multiple major waves seem to be arriving simultaneously—technologies like the cloud, AI, AR/VR, not to mention more esoteric projects like supersonic planes and hyperloops.    What’s more, rather than being concentrated narrowly in a personal computer industry that was essentially a niche market, today’s new technologies impact nearly every part of the economy, creating many new opportunities.   This trend holds tremendous promise!    Precision medicine will use computing power to revolutionize health care.    Smart grids use software to dramatically improve power efficiency and enable the spread of renewable energy sources like solar roofs.    And computational biology might allow us to improve life itself.      “Quantum Growth-Hacking”  can help these advances spread and magnify their sorely needed impact without being eradicated by competitors and hijackers + without dealing with a complex hierarchy bureaucracy like a rigid corporation.   *If You are Interested to Rapidly Scale-Up Your Ventures, Let’s See If You are a Great Fit!   #founders #software #tech #startup #saas #unicorn #ipo #owner

Farmers across Meghalaya (And the other regions of the North East) are seeing a reduction of yield from their crops owing to a multitude of reasons including land use patterns, choice of crops, monoculture, youth leaving the region in search of opportunities etc. A majority of them farm on the slopes and practice traditional methods of shifting cultivation.   Shifting cultivation, though usually badgered by academia and research for the practice of slash and burn actually continues to be one of the most sustainable ways in which farmers can continue to practice subsistence farming that allows multi-cropping, agroforestry resulting in a constant cycle of market linkage and food security.   A lot of efforts take the route of mandating that farmers stop shifting cultivation without looking at a contextual alternative.   In the last month, we have been working together with David Gandhi to spread awareness and build a pilot around a contextual and participatory process for Sloping Agriculture Land Technology (SALT) farming. The goal is to introduce this technique in collaboration with the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) funded projects with MEGHALAYA BASIN MANAGEMENT AGENCY   The goal is to follow a farmer field school approach to help farmers with a contextual alternative that benefits the land, soil, farmers and ecology at large.  The response from the farmers has been very encouraging which is one the main reasons for us to have an aspiration to scale this project towards a Payment for Ecosystem Services structure.   What we are building at Sauramandala Foundation is essentially a learning layer for the state of Meghalaya, with at a team that works across Health, Education, Livelihoods, Energy and Ecology that is trained to identify and understand the problem statements well, we are then able to provide rich insights, access to the ground, government partnerships to the sector at large and have an impact on policy level changes, pilot implementations, innovations and helping our partners scale. The coming years look exciting with the launch of a series of Youth Centers and a rural focused fellowship program that launch by the end of the month.  Rainmatter Foundation Sameer Shisodia #SALTFarming #climateaction #soilhealth SauraMandala Foundation #sdgs2030 #ruraldevelopment #agriculture

IT Development Manager Johannesburg Northern Suburbs Manage and guide a team of developers in their day-to-day activities in an efficient and professional manner, ensuring all team targets are met. Duties & Responsibilities INTERNAL PROCESS •Analyse and solve problems identified by the business and stakeholders through the coordination of the development team •Manage, monitor and control the analysis, design, implementation and execution of software development within the development team •Extend and maintain existing and new software systems and services according to business needs. •Continuously improve code quality, system design and processes •Collaborate with the business to understand and implement complex requirements according to their needs •Communicate with a broader team that includes analysts, engineers and quality assurance testers in order to coordinate and document development and testing •Review and quality assure deliverables in order to ensure quality standards are upheld •Manage the development schedule and monitor, measure, control and report on development progress including the quality status and unit testing results •Ensure the development environment is suitable before development begins and is managed during the software development life cycle (SDLC) •Represent the development team in management, business and inter-team meetings, such as Change Advisory Board (CAB) •Collaborator between operations team and development team •Be actively involved during high priority operational issues   CLIENT •Provide authoritative expertise and advice to clients and stakeholders •Build and maintain collaborative, professional relationships with clients and stakeholders •Deliver on service level agreements made with clients and stakeholders in order to ensure that expectations are managed •Participate and contribute to a culture which builds rewarding relationships, facilitates feedback and provides exceptional client service  PEOPLE •Create a positive work climate and culture to energise employees, give meaning to work, minimise work disruption and maximise employee productivity •Demonstrate exemplary leadership behaviour, through personal involvement, commitment and dedication in support of organisational values •Drive a culture that guides and directs best practice, fostering an environment of continuous learning, improvement and cohesiveness •Enable a learning and growth culture whereby information regarding successes, issues, trends and ideas are actively shared between team members •Assist in effective workforce planning practices to ensure that staffing requirements are accurately forecasted •Identify employee growth and development needs and schedule interventions to enable ongoing development, training and personal growth •Effectively manage performance within the team in order to ensure business objectives are achieved •Encourage innovation, change agility and collaboration within the team

USE DISCERNMENT...  Pleasant Greetings, Friends.  Today's post is inspired by David Wee, about friends and how you make them.  BTW, David is an thought provoking and insightful leader on this platform, and I learn and glean from him regularly.  Thank you for sharing the gift of yourself with me and this community, David!   RELATIONSHIPS MATTER.  I think we know it but can take this fact for granted.  Success comes from relationships.  People get involved in personal, academic, or professional projects with individuals they know, love, and trust.  Proverbs 18:24 talks about a friend who sticks closer than a brother.  I think we can use the word friend too liberally.  IMHO, we do the same for the word love or excellent, etc.  If an individual, such as yourself, has good, close, intimate friends...and I mean these are the folks who "do LIFE with you" and, especially "REAL LIFE", meaning when trouble, trial, challenge, or adversity punches you in the gut - expectedly or by surprise...you are REALLY BLESSED!  Real friendship requires relationship, and that takes work.  I ASK YOU:  Nowadays, do people really want to put forth that effort?  I hope so because we are hardwired by GOD to be relational, to be better together.  My best friend's son said recently that real friends can be hard to come by at school because some people hang out with you and then flake (leave you and not care).  This is sad yet it is also real life, and we must know how to handle it.  Be discerning.  Covid caused life to change dramatically and rapidly.  With it also came positive changes (remote work, innovation, etc.) and isolation, loneliness, and health issues.  I highly recommend that each of us utilize discernment.  Discernment is the ability to judge well.  For me, that ability comes from reading Proverbs and The Bible.  The Bible Is GOD'S Book of Success, and is full of Wisdom.  And, pursuing Wisdom has its benefits...but that is for to discover independently and for another post.  Take actor, writer, director, producer, Tyler Perry's advice and learn to appreciate who and what people are:  a leaf, a branch, a tree (roots).  And, if people who want to walk out of your life and relationship with you:  Be thankful for that season (of relationship), LET THEM GO, and keep your Peace.  To learn more about Tyler's analogy, click on the link in the Comments.  It is wise counsel!  I welcome your thoughts in the comments.  #MyLovelyPeople #succes #leadership #mindset #relationships

New Post: 1017 - https://lnkd.in/dhwNPZJf.    Assignment Instructions LITERATURE REVIEW Overview  For this assignment, you will develop a condensed literature review on a topic you chose. The literature you select should be relevant to a current issue, problem, innovation, change, or trend in your field or specialization. My Specialized Field is Healthcare Administration     Writing a literature review is a key part of academic work. A literature review is a piece of writing that describes what has been learned about a topic through previous research efforts. The literature review is essentially a report on work previously done in a field, to show an understanding of the context for your own writing.  Your literature review should include a minimum of five references from peer-reviewed journal articles related to your field or specialization.   Literature Review Guide  A literature review is not a summary of individual sources in a list, such as in the form of an annotated bibliography. Instead, the literature review should integrate in-text citations within the paragraphs to support your analysis of the scholarly readings you selected. You will seek key themes from the different scholarly journals.  Use Academic Writer for guidance in citing sources and formatting your paper in proper APA style. See the Evidence and APA section of the Writing Center for instructions on accessing and using Academic Writer.   Critical thinking: Be sure to analyze and evaluate the articles, not just report what was written. What should you add?  Integration: Integrate information from across the sources in your review. Look for themes and commonalities. Do not just review one article after another in a linear fashion. Use headings and subheadings to organize your paper around themes you identify.  Review of the rubric: Apply critical thinking to analyze scholarly articles and point out conflicting evidence or perspectives. Apply critical thinking to evaluate scholarly articles and identify criteria used for evaluation. Synthesize information to identify missing information that limits understanding of the topic.  Critical Thinking Examples  Apply principles of critical thinking to analyze scholarly articles and point out any conflicting evidence or perspectives. For example:   "Articles X and Y (citation) promote a constructivist approach, which is in direct contrast to the behaviorist approach advocated in article Z (citation)."  Apply principles of critical thinking to evaluate scholarly articles and identify the criteria used for the evaluation. For example:  "There is a weakness in the inference made by the author (citation), as the conclusion of XXXX was not clearly supported by the data." "The author (citation) never clearly defined the concept of XYZ."  Synthesize information gathered in a review of scholarly literature and identify any missing information that limits understanding of the topic. For example:  "The five artic

And I now even have a flavour created in my name  by our very own Ben Kranen ,Principal Flavourist from a description coming from the team !My heart is full of gratitude, it is full of pride . AAREP ATL recognizes James “Jay” Bailey as a Pillar in the CRE industry.  Committed to living by his personal motto, “Build As We Climb”, change agent, thought leader, entrepreneur, and emerging philanthropist, James M. Bailey has dedicated his life to serving others.   James serves as President and CEO of the Russell Innovation Center for Entrepreneurs (RICE). Honoring the great legacy and visionary business leadership of Herman J. Russell, Sr., he will lead the development of the largest center in America, dedicated to empowering Black entrepreneurs and small business owners; over 50,000 square feet designed to inspire ideas, create jobs, grow companies, and increase wealth in the community.   An Atlanta native and die-hard Georgia Bulldog, James has a proven track record of success, recognized by 3 U.S. Presidents for his leadership and community efforts. In 2012, James was one of eight Americans honored at the White House as a “Champion of Change: Following in the Footsteps of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.”  Dedicated to service, James is a National Point of Light Award and Presidential Lifetime Volunteer Service Award recipient. James has served on numerous boards including the Metro Atlanta and the Georgia Chamber Board of Directors, the Atlanta Beltline TAD Advisory Committee, a Georgia Forestry Foundation Trustee, and Chairman of Citizens Trust Bank’s, Next Generation Advisory Board.   A graduate of Leadership Georgia, Leadership Atlanta, and the Regional Leadership Institute, James was also named to both the Atlanta Business Chronicle and Georgia Trend Magazine’s “40 Under 40 Best and Brightest Leaders of the Future”, while Atlanta Magazine recognized him as one of the city’s most powerful leaders.   He is a recipient of the coveted Whitney M. Young National Community Service Medallion, the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Drum Major for Service Award, a New Leaders Council Fellow, member of Alpha Phi Alpha and the 100 Black Men of Atlanta.    Thank you Jay Bailey for leading the way in the Construction industry and helping make room for the next generation.  #jamesbailey #hjrussellinnovation #aarepatl #weopendoors #minoritiesincre

“The secret of getting ahead is getting started.”  To us, our employees are more than High Vis wearing, number crunching, project managers. Around the UK we are employing forward thinkers, paving the way for change and encouraging innovation and efficiency.  When I was first starting out in my career, I was given a lot of responsibility but very little authority. Business decisions lead to high levels of micromanaging, which left teams feeling frustrated and sometimes powerless. I soon realised that this approach was not only stifling creativity, but it was also preventing development in the skills I and my colleagues needed to be successful in our roles.  Since then, I have made it a point to empower the people I work with, whether they are direct reports or members of my team. I have found that when people feel trusted and empowered, they are more engaged and productive.  As part of our team you can contribute to shaping how we design and deliver our network  – through experience, suggestions and technology. From improving the way we interact with each other, down to the type of fibre that delivers our super fast speeds, we aim to promote opportunities to break new ground and create substance on our journey.  With 7 positions in my team being filled over the past month, we have one remaining - which could be the start of your journey at Connect Fibre…  Please connect with me directly for more details or send your CV to;  DeliveryCV@connectfibre.co.uk  *The role is Work From Home with travel when required.  *UK applicants only please. *No agencies at this time.   #technology #innovation #business #team #network #people #opportunities #projectmanagers #fttp

Today is my 11th year anniversary at Airbnb. What an amazing ride! I could have not imagined how impactful and transformational this job would be in my life. It’s been a privilege to be part of this story and to have my life tied to this legacy. I am grateful for the opportunity to lead with advocacy, innovation, inclusion and authenticity contributing to a more connected world and in service of community. Airbnb has been a place of growth, acceptance, challenge, and opportunity where I feel seen, heard and valued. The changes and growth I have witnessed in the tech space during these 11 years are a testament of what can happen when we act with intentionality, advocate for fairness and lead with intention. It fills my heart to see so many stories of transformation, contribution, innovation, and hard work marking a decade of advocacy for diversity and inclusion in tech. URGs belong in tech. We are in every successful company, we bring our values, our resiliency, our commitment and more important our empirical perspective and experiences. We make companies stronger, products better and communities more united. I am so proud and grateful for the work, and everything we have accomplished in these 11 years. And the best is yet to come! #community #job #tech #opportunity #inclusion #diversityandinclusion #latinxleaders #latinasintech #latinas #boricua #diversityintech #diversitymatters

While my time at NYSHEX has come to an end, it is certainly not good bye, but see you down the road.  I am beyond grateful to have worked at a company with a meaningful purpose and well-defined mission, to enable reliable shipping while improving trust and uniting global commerce, making it more efficient, stable, and predictable.  The opportunity to find mutually beneficial supply chain solutions with technology and product innovation, during one of the most volatile shipping environments was exciting and galvanized our team of amazing people.     Thank you to Gordon Trouncer Downes for the opportunity to work with a real visionary and advocate for positive change in the shipping industry.  Thank you to the entire organization for teaching and challenging me to be better everyday.  Thank you to our wonderful members who are innovative trailblazers helping define the future of supply chain.  Finally, special thanks to my podcast partner Donald Davis for helping create and share his lifetime of experience through #SupplyChainSecrets.      I’m looking forward to my next adventure and will share more soon.   #NYSHEX

After almost five years at NIE, I'm ready for a fresh start and a new challenge.  I spent the week reflecting on the things I learned at NIE that will help shape the rest of my career. While the list is long, a few stand out for me. Working at NIE changed the way I see education, what culture can mean, how being agile is critical for success, and how challenging the status quo should not be a luxury but a necessity. It was an incredible experience to be part of an institution that cared about its people - above all else. I learned what it feels like to work for and with people who deeply care about and support each other – in good times and in bad. I leave NIE with a full heart – one overflowing with gratitude. I’ll work hard to recreate this in the next chapter of my career.   Thank you, Prof Chew-Hung Chang, for your leadership and support. Thank you, Assoc Prof Liu Woon Chia, for bringing me to this institution when there was much work to be done. You're such an inspirational leader, and it's been an honour to work with you.   Over the last couple of years, I worked very hard to develop a leadership team that can carry the vision, mission and culture of what is today the Centre for Innovation in Learning forward. Today I believe I leave the team better than I found it.    While I will miss my friends and colleagues at NIE very much, I'm also extremely excited about my next endeavour. I'll share more about that in a couple of weeks.   Thanks for the great memories, NIE! #education #innovation #people
